facts.text: Badrinarayan and Lakshminarayan were two brothers; Badrinarayan elder carried on business at Raipur, Lakshminarayan younger at ancestral village Tirora.
Lakshminarayan's first wife died in 1919 leaving a son and daughter; son died after 1922 marriage to Mst. Chaltibai; daughter Mst. Jamnabai married to Chotteylal.
Lakshminarayan died on January 6, 1936 of heart disease, leaving estate in schs. B, C, D valued at Rs. 30,000.
Appellant Kishori Lal, youngest son of Badrinarayan (aged 13 in 1935), claims adoption by Lakshminarayan in Jyestha (May-June) 1935 due to heart trouble despairing of son.
After adoption, appellant resided with Lakshminarayan, performed obsequies, placed on gaddi, turban tied; on 13th day (tervi) taken in lap by respondent with consent of relations.

Respondent continued to accept and treat appellant as adopted son up to 1946; performed his marriage in 1942; appellant managed estate after majority; partition in Badrinarayan family on October 30, 1943 where appellant got no share due to adoption.

Respondent denied adoption and acceptance; illiterate pardanashin woman; reposed confidence in Badrinarayan who managed estate, accounts, court work; signed papers without understanding, sometimes blank.
Disputes led to proceedings under ss.107/145 CrPC; receiver appointed; Magistrate order May 19, 1947 directed civil suit; challenged unsuccessfully.
Suit by Mst. Chaltibai for declaration sch. B,C properties hers as heir, possession of sch. D.
Trial court (Additional District Judge, Bhandara, July 25, 1951): adoption proved, but no estoppel; suit dismissed.
High Court of Nagpur (Sept 28, 1953, First Appeal No. 115 of 1951): reversed on factum of adoption (not proved), upheld no estoppel; allowed appeal, decreed for plaintiff.
No formal deed of adoption; proved by 6 witnesses (Mohanlal, Badrinarayan, Narsingdas, Shankarlal, Chattarpatti, Kishorilal) + Sobharam for admission.

Adoption formalities: tilak, turban by Lakshminarayan; pansupari distribution; no lap by adoptive mother at time, no invitations, no publicity, no feast, no priest, no Ganesh puja consistently, respondent not present.
No accounts produced for adoption expenses or travel; accounts only for tervi.
Sale deed Jan 24, 1938 by respondent states adoption after Lakshminarayan's death by her under his authority and family consent; witnessed by Badrinarayan.
After alleged adoption, appellant returned to Raipur school; school certificate shows student at Tirora June 22, 1936 to June 30, 1937 as son of Badrinarayan.
Succession certificate application March 21, 1936 by respondent as guardian mother; drafts showed Badrinarayan as guardian; in English, not explained to her.
Bahi entry July 21, 1944: appellant as adopted son; contradicted by later entry March 2, 1947 as son of Badrinarayan.
Adhikar patra May 4, 1946: refers to mother-son relation; but respondent denying adoption then.
Mutation April 8, 1936 in favour of respondent in some places; appellant under her or Badrinarayan's guardianship.
Partition in Badrinarayan family October 30, 1943; appellant no share due to adoption.

legal_issues.text: Did the deceased Lakshminarayan validly adopt the defendant No. 2 in the bright fortnight of Jyestha (June), 1935 A. D.?
Was the adoption valid according to law?
Had the plaintiff all along recognised the adoption as valid and legal and had she been treating defendant No. 2 as Lakshminarayan's son all along? If so, result?

petitioner_arguments.text: Evidence of six witnesses and Sobharam proves adoption in Jyestha 1935 at Tirora house; formalities: tilak, turban, pansupari.
Respondent estopped by representations in documents, proceedings, actions (obsequies, marriage, possession); altered position: transplanted to another family, deprived of natural family share.
Admissions by respondent shift burden to her to disprove adoption.
Long course of conduct, treatment as son, possession, family recognition require appraising evidence to hold adoption proved.

respondent_arguments.text: Denied adoption and any treatment or acceptance as adopted son.
Illiterate pardanashin; trusted Badrinarayan who managed everything; signed blindly.
In criminal case, appellant claimed adoption 6 months prior to death, which she denied.

court_reasoning.text: No formal deed; oral evidence insufficient, contradictory on details, ceremonies; no accounts, no publicity, no invitations, respondent absent; suspicious circumstances require strong proof for adoption changing succession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence free from suspicion of fraud needed; failure to produce accounts suspicious.

court_reasoning.text: Sale deed 1938 states adoption after death by respondent; appellant returned to Raipur post-adoption; school as Badrinarayan's son.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court correctly held factum of adoption not established.

court_reasoning.text: No estoppel: both parties knew true facts (no adoption); estoppel inapplicable where truth known to both; documents not admissions of lifetime adoption by husband.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Documents consistent with post-death adoption by widow, not by husband.

court_reasoning.text: Obsequies, lap-taking, residence, possession, marriage do not prove or confirm adoption when factum disproved; course of conduct/acquiescence cannot establish disproved adoption.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Admissions not conclusive; onus irrelevant after full evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent young widow, pardanashin, dependent on Badrinarayan family; admissions carry little weight.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Circumstances explain conduct without implying adoption.

holdings.text: Factum of adoption by Lakshminarayan not proved.
No estoppel against respondent as both parties knew no adoption occurred.
Estoppel does not confer status; inapplicable when true facts known to both.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court judgment reversing trial court; held factum of adoption not proved and no estoppel; plaintiff Mst. Chaltibai entitled to properties as heir.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration and possession to plaintiff as per High Court decree

key_quotes.text: As an adoption results in changing the course of succession... it is necessary that the evidence to support it should be such that it is free from all suspicion of fraud and so consistent and probable as to leave no occasion for doubting its truth.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: There can be no estoppel where the truth of the matter is known to both the parties.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The correct rule of estoppel applicable in the case of adoption is that it does not confer status.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits of estoppel in adoption cases
